title: Shia LaBeouf embraces co-star Zack Gottsagen at the BFI premiere of The Peanut Butter Falcon
text:
They take on the leading roles in the hotly anticipated drama which sees a young man with Down Syndrome follow his dream of becoming a professional wrestler.

And Shia LaBeouf and Zack Gottsagen showed off their close bond as they attended the premiere of The Peanut Butter Falcon during the BFI London Film Festival on Thursday.

The actors, who play Zak and his unlikely friend and coach Tyler looked delighted as they embraced on the red carpet, with Shia, 33, chatting to his dapper co-star.

Sharp: Transformers star Shia cut a dapper figure in a sharply tailored chocolate brown suit, which featured a shirt with an oversize collar and a double breasted blazer

Transformers star Shia cut a dapper figure in a sharply tailored chocolate brown suit, which featured a shirt with an oversize collar and a double breasted blazer.

He paired this with a pair of matching trousers which were worn tucked into patent leather boots.

The star wore his brunette locks cropped close with a distinguished moustache and goatee adorning his chiselled jaw.

Zak, 34, looked debonair in a silk lavender patterned tie, teamed with an amethyst shirt and a suave black suit as he promoted his debut film.

Dapper: He paired this with a pair of matching trousers which were worn tucked into patent leather boots

The Peanut Butter Falcon follows Zak (Zack Gottsagen), a young man with Down Syndrome who runs away from a residential nursing home to follow his dream of learning how to become a professional wrestler, and along his travels he finds an unlikely coach in Tyler (LaBeouf).

Inspired, Zak leaves the comforts of home and his caregiver Eleanor (Dakota Johnson) to attend a wrestling school of his idol, The Salt Water Redneck (Thomas Haden Church).

Eleanor has been given the task of tracking Zak down before something tragic happens to him.

A strange turn of events eventually pairs Zak on the road with Tyler, a small time outlaw on the run.

Movie star: The star wore his brunette locks cropped close with a distinguished moustache and goatee adorning his chiselled jaw.

Movie debut: Zak, 34, looked debonair in a silk lavender patterned tie, teamed with an amethyst shirt and a suave black suit as he promoted his debut feature-length film

It quickly becomes apparent that the two have a bond, resulting in Tyler becoming his coach, ally, and eventually his friend.

The heartfelt adventure was produced by the Oscar-nominated Little Miss Sunshine team of Albert Berger and Ron Yerxa and also stars Bruce Dern, John Hawkes and Jon Bernthal.

During the premiere at this year's SXSW Festival in March, it ended up being one of the breakout hits, winning the Narrative Spotlight Award.

Zak initially crossed paths with the film's directors Tyler Nilson and Michael Schwartz at a 2013 acting workshop in Santa Monica, California for disabled people, according to the AP.

After Gottsagen, who has Down syndrome, expressed an interest in appearing in films, Schwartz said, 'We had to have a really frank conversation about how there aren't many opportunities for people with Down syndrome to act in movies that go into theaters.

For the fans: Shia happily posed up for selfies with some of his die-hard fans

Line-up: Director Michael Schwartz, director Tyler Nilson, Zack and Shia posed up

New film: The Peanut Butter Falcon follows Zak (Zack Gottsagen), a young man with Down Syndrome who runs away from a residential nursing home to follow his dream of learning how to become a professional wrestler

'He kind of got really emotional and he just said, "Well, let's do it together then! It was his idea. It was a great idea."'

LaBeouf told the AP he's better since meeting and bonding with Gottsagen two years ago, and has 'adopted a lot of his self-love and his confidence,' which has had a positive impact on his state of mind.

'It's leading to self-love, which is leading to an ability to receive love, which is what was lacking in my life,' said the Transformers star. 'And I would run to alcohol. I just hated myself. Just a big self-hater.'

LaBeouf opened up about how he bonded with Gottsagen, and how it helped him become sober after an extended period of boozing.

'He knows about my pain intimately. We'd be sitting there watching wrestling every night. He'd be eating ice cream. I'd be drinking gin. I'd tell him, "You gotta stop eating all that ice cream." He'd say, "You gotta stop drinking that gin."

'This man's a year older than me. He's been acting longer than me and he's healthier than I am. He has more friends than I have, has longer lasting loving relationships.'

The film, which captured the Audience Award at the SXSW festival earlier this year, also features Bruce Dern, Jon Bernthal, John Hawkes and Thomas Haden Church, as well as professional wrestling legends Jake 'The Snake' Roberts and Mick Foley.

The film opens in UK theatres on October 18.
